In summary: Expanding the EITC has bipartisan support, would increase wages for low-income Americans, and reduce unemployment. Seems like a no-brainer to me.

If the EITC were expanded on a national level, the effects would be even greater. An estimated 15 million workers would qualify for benefits. This would cost a fraction of what Trump‚Äôs tax cuts have cost us and have an overwhelmingly positive effect on working Americans.

New York City recently experimented with expanding the EITC and the results were positive. Not only did incomes for low-wage workers increase, but unemployment went down. The effects were the largest on the most vulnerable demographics, including the previously incarcerated.

Here‚Äôs one way we can reverse this trend: We must expand the Earned Income Tax Credit. I‚Äôve cosponsored legislation to do this. The EITC has long-term bipartisan support, and it should be expanded to include a broader range of the workforce.

The economy isn‚Äôt working for working people. Too much of the benefits of recent economic growth are concentrated at the top & in a few zip codes. And the persistent feeling of threat that the military nurse originally shared with me is being exposed by generations of women who are bravely sharing stories that they‚Äôve held within themselves for decades.

The #MeToo & #WhyIDidntReport stories that so many courageous women have shared over the past year, & in particular over the past week, are strikingly similar to the stories shared with me by the victims of military sexual trauma.
I spent the next 11 years digging into this issue & working to prevent the alarming prevalence of discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual assault, and professional retaliation in the U.S. military.
She had never been assaulted but lived with the persistent feeling of threat from her fellow servicemembers.

#HR6729 undermines consumer privacy by shielding banks from liability for violating agreements with their customers to protect their personal information.
#HR6729 can even protect disclosures that were not made in good faith. Someone could share a false accusation and still be immune.
Even if the accused is innocent and never charged with a crime, their reputation may be destroyed, and banks may choose to close their accounts, effectively blocking them from the financial system.
#HR6729 also invites due process violations. The bill allows nonprofits to go to banks and accuse people of serious crimes, while being shielded from liability.
#HR6729 applies #PatriotAct language to new categories of information, giving the government more power to engage in warrantless data collection and sharing‚Äîincluding on Americans.

#HR6729 is described as involving voluntary data sharing, but it also includes language from a section of the #PatriotAct that the government has used to warrantlessly demand customer information from thousands of companies.

Our bill attempts to address this by disclosing case records so that private detectives, historians, victims, and victims‚Äô families may access these files, pursue leads, and document these tragic events.
